isis.stitle: Recall 98501 - Air Compressor Discharge Line on Caterpillar C10 and C12 Engines on 9100 and 9200 Model Vehicles

recall.subject: Air Compressor Discharge Line on Caterpillar C10 and C12 Engines on 9100 and 9200 Model Vehicles

defect.para: This Recall applies to 9100 and 9200 Models with Caterpillar C10 and C12 engines built from 4/9/96 through 11/20/97.

A P-clamp was omitted from the rear of the engine that supports the air compressor discharge line. Vehicle vibration could cause the unsupported line to fail. This could deplete the air system and cause the parking brakes to apply. This condition could cause the vehicle to slow down or stop unexpectedly, and could cause a vehicular accident resulting in property damage or personal injury, or both.

Owners will be notified of this campaign on their vehicles by Navistar. A listing of owner names and addresses will have been furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers of follow up with owners to have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

step1.para: Attach the bracket P/N 864340R1 to the back of the engine. Mount the bracket so it has between a 20 - 45 degree downward angle. This will lower the compressor discharge line to clear the floor. Attach the P-clamp P/N 505194C1 to the compressor discharge line and bolt to the bracket. Refer to Figure 1.
Remove the stud that is located just beneath the bracket with bolt P/N 477884C1 as the stud interferes with the fuel hosing. Refer to Figure 1.
Install fuel line P-clamp along with the compressor discharge line P-clamp on the new bracket. Refer to Figure 2.
Tie the fuel hosing with a tie strap at either side of the P-clamp. Refer to Figure 2.

entry.para: Attach bracket and P-clamp. Remove stud and replace bolt.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location. Dearlers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his vehicle as soon as possible.

claims.para: Refer to Dealer Warranty Manual for procedures to conduct Recall Campaigns.
